articles.headline: Putin Led a Complex Cyberattack Scheme to Aid Trump, Report Finds
articles.snippet: U.S. intelligence agencies presented their unanimous conclusions to Donald J. Trump, bringing the leaders of these agencies face to face with their most vocal skeptic, the president-elect.
articles.abstract: U.S. intelligence agencies presented their unanimous conclusions to Donald J. Trump, bringing the leaders of these agencies face to face with their most vocal skeptic, the president-elect.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia directed a vast cyberattack aimed at denying Hillary Clinton the presidency and installing Donald J. Trump in the Oval Office, the nation’s top intelligence agencies said in an extraordinary report they delivered on Friday to Mr. Trump.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Florida Airport Assailant May Have Heard Voices Urging Violence, Officials Say
articles.snippet: Federal law enforcement officials identified the suspect in a shooting that left at least five dead as a 26-year-old former National Guardsmen.
articles.abstract: Federal law enforcement officials identified the suspect in a shooting that left at least five dead as a 26-year-old former National Guardsmen.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — Federal law enforcement officials said they were investigating whether the gunman who opened fire on Friday at the airport here, killing five people and wounding eight, was mentally disturbed and heard voices in his head telling him to commit acts of violence.
articles.byline: By Lizette Alvarez, Richard Fausset and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Student Victims Seek to Become Creditors in ITT Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: Five former ITT students took matters into their own hands this week by petitioning a federal bankruptcy court to consider loan forgiveness as part of the company’s liquidation.
articles.abstract: Five former ITT students took matters into their own hands this week by petitioning a federal bankruptcy court to consider loan forgiveness as part of the company’s liquidation.
articles.lead_paragraph: It seems only right that victims of predatory for-profit education companies should have their student loans forgiven. After all, in addition to being left with mountains of debt, former students have worthless degrees from schools that no longer exist, such as those once operated by the defunct Corinthian Colleges or ITT Educational Services.

articles.headline: Volkswagen Said to Be Close to Settling Justice Inquiry Into Emissions
articles.snippet: The settlement, for more than $2 billion, in a federal criminal inquiry could come as early as next week, people briefed on the negotiations said.
articles.abstract: The settlement, for more than $2 billion, in a federal criminal inquiry could come as early as next week, people briefed on the negotiations said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Volkswagen is nearing a deal to pay more than $2 billion to resolve a federal criminal investigation into its cheating on emissions tests, according to three people briefed on the negotiations.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing, Hiroko Tabuchi and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Russian Intervention in American Election Was No One-Off
articles.snippet: The hacking, detailed in a report by three intelligence agencies, was only one element in an information war that has gone on under the radar for years.
articles.abstract: The hacking, detailed in a report by three intelligence agencies, was only one element in an information war that has gone on under the radar for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: The intelligence agencies’ report on the Russian intervention in the American presidential election portrays it as just one piece of an old-fashioned Soviet-style propaganda campaign. But it was a campaign made enormously more powerful by the tools of the cyberage: private emails pilfered by hackers, an internet that reaches into most American homes, social media to promote its revelations and smear enemies.

articles.headline: Trump Nominees’ Filings Threaten to Overwhelm Federal Ethics Office
articles.snippet: Rex W. Tillerson’s financial disclosure, showing the stocks and other assets he has to sell off to avoid conflicts, is among a wave of filings for what may be the wealthiest cabinet in modern history.
articles.abstract: Rex W. Tillerson’s financial disclosure, showing the stocks and other assets he has to sell off to avoid conflicts, is among a wave of filings for what may be the wealthiest cabinet in modern history.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rex W. Tillerson owns more than $50 million of Exxon Mobil stock, has earned an annual salary of $10 million and holds a range of positions — from director at the Boy Scouts of America to the managing director of a Texas horse and cattle ranch.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Steve Eder

articles.headline: In Zimbabwe, a First Lady Exerts Her Power
articles.snippet: Grace Mugabe, the wife of President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, is one of the main actors maneuvering to succeed him.
articles.abstract: Grace Mugabe, the wife of President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, is one of the main actors maneuvering to succeed him.
articles.lead_paragraph: MASVINGO, Zimbabwe — The first lady of Zimbabwe’s display of power was unspoken, though clear, during the governing party’s annual congress, as she focused her speech on new party regalia featuring a teacup-shaped image of her country.

articles.headline: Jared Kushner, a Trump In-Law and Adviser, Chases a Chinese Deal
articles.snippet: As Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law prepares for a White House role, his undisclosed talks with a secretive Chinese company highlight potential conflicts of interest.
articles.abstract: As Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law prepares for a White House role, his undisclosed talks with a secretive Chinese company highlight potential conflicts of interest.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the night of Nov. 16, a group of executives gathered in a private dining room of the restaurant La Chine at the Waldorf Astoria hotel in Midtown Manhattan. The table was laden with Chinese delicacies and $2,100 bottles of Château Lafite Rothschild. At one end sat Wu Xiaohui, the chairman of the Waldorf’s owner, Anbang Insurance Group, a Chinese financial behemoth with estimated assets of $285 billion and an ownership structure shrouded in mystery. Close by sat Jared Kushner, a major New York real estate investor whose father-in-law, Donald J. Trump, had just been elected president of the United States.
articles.byline: By Susanne Craig, Jo Becker and Jesse Drucker

articles.headline: Senate Confirmation Hearings to Begin Without All Background Checks
articles.snippet: The leader of the Office of Government Ethics said he knew of no occasion when the Senate had held a confirmation hearing before his office completed its review.
articles.abstract: The leader of the Office of Government Ethics said he knew of no occasion when the Senate had held a confirmation hearing before his office completed its review.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Senate Republicans embark on a flurry of confirmation hearings this week, several of Donald J. Trump’s appointees have yet to complete the background checks and ethics clearances customarily required before the Senate begins to consider cabinet-level nominees.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: In Year Before Florida Shooting, Suspect’s Problems Multiplied
articles.snippet: The police were called repeatedly to Esteban Santiago’s home about domestic disturbances, and the National Guard kicked him out after nearly a decade of service.
articles.abstract: The police were called repeatedly to Esteban Santiago’s home about domestic disturbances, and the National Guard kicked him out after nearly a decade of service.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — Signs of Esteban Santiago’s unraveling had mounted over the past year. But it was not until early November, when he walked into an F.B.I. office carrying an ammunition clip — leaving a pistol and his infant son in his car — to complain about a C.I.A. plot against him, that his behavior became disturbing enough to earn him a short stay in a psychiatric hospital unit.
articles.byline: By Lizette Alvarez, Frances Robles and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: ‘What’s the Big Deal?’ Ask Trump Voters on Russia Hacking Report
articles.snippet: Supporters of President-elect Donald J. Trump have dismissed a report by U.S. intelligence officials accusing Russia of interfering in the election to undermine Hillary Clinton.
articles.abstract: Supporters of President-elect Donald J. Trump have dismissed a report by U.S. intelligence officials accusing Russia of interfering in the election to undermine Hillary Clinton.
articles.lead_paragraph: COVINGTON, La. — “Sour grapes,” explained Bob Marino, 79, weighing in on the recent spycraft bombshell from the corner table of a local McDonald’s.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: Jeff Sessions, a Lifelong Outsider, Finds the Inside Track
articles.snippet: An alliance with Donald J. Trump has paid off for Mr. Sessions in a fashion that few who know him ever imagined: Within days, he could be confirmed as attorney general.
articles.abstract: An alliance with Donald J. Trump has paid off for Mr. Sessions in a fashion that few who know him ever imagined: Within days, he could be confirmed as attorney general.
articles.lead_paragraph: During nearly two decades in the Senate, Jeff Sessions had never endorsed anyone in a presidential primary. But last January, the Alabama Republican, afraid that his party was floundering, sent a five-point questionnaire to all its presidential contenders to determine who might deserve his support.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Santa Delivered the Drone. But Not the Safety and Skill to Fly Them.
articles.snippet: The holiday season was a boom time for drone sales, bringing a heightened risk to people and property, particularly when neophytes are at the controls.
articles.abstract: The holiday season was a boom time for drone sales, bringing a heightened risk to people and property, particularly when neophytes are at the controls.
articles.lead_paragraph: My dad got a drone for Christmas.My dad lost a drone on Christmas.

articles.headline: Death of Iran’s Rafsanjani Removes Influential Voice Against Hard-Liners
articles.snippet: Mr. Rafsanjani, 82, was a main voice in Iran calling for outreach to the West. His death is also a reminder of a looming generational leadership change.
articles.abstract: Mr. Rafsanjani, 82, was a main voice in Iran calling for outreach to the West. His death is also a reminder of a looming generational leadership change.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — With the death of Ayatollah Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani on Sunday, Iran’s political factions knew immediately that any space by reformers to maneuver had just significantly decreased.

articles.headline: Detroit Auto Show Reveals a Google-Designed Van That Could Steer the Industry
articles.snippet: The minivan, built by Fiat Chrysler with self-driving sensors from Waymo, is the first heavyweight collaboration between a major automaker and one of Silicon Valley’s elite.
articles.abstract: The minivan, built by Fiat Chrysler with self-driving sensors from Waymo, is the first heavyweight collaboration between a major automaker and one of Silicon Valley’s elite.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — There are shiny new sport utility vehicles, brawny pickups and sleek sedans. But the unlikely star of the annual Detroit auto show is an odd-looking minivan capable of driving itself.

articles.headline: Sticker Shock, and Maybe Nausea, Hamper Sales of Virtual Reality Gear
articles.snippet: One of the most hyped technologies of 2016 has a way to go before it becomes mainstream, with product sales held back by high costs, ergonomic issues and other factors.
articles.abstract: One of the most hyped technologies of 2016 has a way to go before it becomes mainstream, with product sales held back by high costs, ergonomic issues and other factors.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — For a technology to crack the mainstream, there is an unspoken understanding: It shouldn’t make the people who use it want to throw up.

articles.headline: Data Could Be the Next Tech Hot Button for Regulators
articles.snippet: For decades, dominance in the technology industry was based on software or hardware. Now it is increasingly based on who owns the best data.
articles.abstract: For decades, dominance in the technology industry was based on software or hardware. Now it is increasingly based on who owns the best data.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wealth and influence in the technology business have always been about gaining the upper hand in software or the machines that software ran on.

articles.headline: In Election Hacking, Julian Assange’s Years-Old Vision Becomes Reality
articles.snippet: In a 2006 essay, Mr. Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, outlined the politically disruptive potential of technology. Hillary Clinton’s loss might be a realization of his vision.
articles.abstract: In a 2006 essay, Mr. Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, outlined the politically disruptive potential of technology. Hillary Clinton’s loss might be a realization of his vision.
articles.lead_paragraph: At first blush, there’s a baffling, inside-out quality to Julian Assange’s latest star turn in our shambolic national story.

articles.headline: Airstrikes by Russia Buttress Turkey in Battle vs. ISIS
articles.snippet: The deepening partnership between Russia and Turkey could marginalize the United States in the struggle to shape Syria’s future.
articles.abstract: The deepening partnership between Russia and Turkey could marginalize the United States in the struggle to shape Syria’s future.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russian warplanes have carried out airstrikes to support Turkey’s offensive in northern Syria against the Islamic State, an important evolution in a budding Russian-Turkish partnership. The deepening ties threaten to marginalize the United States in the struggle to shape Syria’s ultimate fate.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Eric Schmitt
